reviewText: I love this show.  It is what "Big Bang" could have been if they were willing to risk being offensive.  The two main characters are aspiring horror movie makers in Holliston MA.  They work at a public assess TV station.  Adam Greene, the creator is also the creator of Hatchet.  He is a real insider in the horror community, and he brings guests (John Landis, Tony Todd, Kane Hodder, etc) into the show - often as themselves.  It's awesome and funny, but there are some jokes and references you won't get unless you're a horror fan.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Similar to another review posted here, I adore this show.  Its fun, quirky, creative and different, a great contrast to the usual painfully artificial shows on mainstream tv.  While the other review provides a great overview of the show's merits, my review focuses on the medium choice - my recommendation is to simply buy the standard definition version.  I'll grant that this show is not a Hollywood production with those kind of budgets, so I'm thankful for what I get.  That said, it would appear almost no work went into engineering the content for blu ray.  Unfortunately, the image feels like a photo file unedited from a low quality camera - exposure is off, color saturation is weak, and overall contrast is lacking.  Sound is the same, not well engineered and peaky and flat.  Again, I adore this show, and you should run, not walk, to own it.  Just save yourself the funds and stick with the standard definition (and this is coming from a blu ray addict).

reviewText: I came to know the FEARnet series "Holliston" backwards. I saw season two before I ever saw season one, which was just recently. I was immediately hooked when I caught it, and was finally able to get my hands on season one. So, what's it about?"Holliston" stars Adam Green and Joe Lynch as, well, Adam and Joe. Two regular, horror movie loving guys living in Holliston, Massachusetts. The guys host a horror movie show on local TV called "The Movie Crypt", while trying to raise funds to shoot the trailer for a movie they want to make, the horror flick "Shinpads". Along the way, the guys are just dealing with regular life, not having any money, and love with the women in their lives. There's Joe's Girlfriend Laura (Laura Ortiz), a sweet, child-like pixie with an adorable voice who has an odd choice of subjects when it comes to her art. Adam's ex is Corri (Corri English), a gorgeous blond who just moves back to town. The kind of girl, as Adam says, "you want to buy ice cream for". Rounding out the cast of characters is Lance Rockitt (Twisted Sister lead singer, Dee Snider), a lost in the 80s glam rock guy who runs the TV station. Then there is Adam's imaginary friend, Oderus Urungus, who lives in his closet and says just about anything he pleases."Holliston" may not be everybody's cup of tea, but what I found incredibly interesting the first time I watched is how much heart it has. Horror fans are not just weirdos like some people think. They are real people like anyone else. They have feelings and a heart. They just happen to like a certain genre that some other people may not like. So what? There is a lot of old school sitcom touches to the series, and not just the heartfelt moments, which escalate in season two. It's a traditional, three camera series with a laugh track. Now, obviously, not all sitcoms have laugh tracks, but this one does and it's horrendous. It had to be intentional because of how bad it is. Just to add to the camp flavor I guess. Anyways, you really start to like these people. You may not be into horror, but you feel like you could be these people, or be friends with them. The acting and writing serves the show well for what kind of show it is and what it's trying to be. And what show is that? A show for horror fans to come together on. It's funny, it's heartfelt, it loves it's horror pedigree and the horror actors (Danielle Harris, Tony Todd, Derek Mears, Bill Moseley, Kane Hodder) who come through, and above all, it's fun. Remember fun? When TV had a lot more escapism that was just to take you away for a 22-44 minute ride? It's raunchy at times, crude at others, but it never talks down to anybody. Instead, it raises a glass to a fan community and says "Here's to us! Let's have some fun".Episodes include: "The Hooker", which is the pilot episode in which Corri comes back to town, but has a sad surprise for Adam. "Camera Rental" has the guys loaning out the TV station equipment in an effort to pay for their 'Shinpads' trailer. "Skunked" has Adam and Joe sharing a very awkward bath together after getting, well, skunked. "Candyman" is a funny episode that has that character's portrayor, Tony Todd, become an unwanted houseguest for Adam and Joe. "Laura's Little Twitter" has Laura finding out just why she has gotten so many followers on Twitter so quickly. The last episode, "Weekend of Horrors", has the gang attending a horror convention so Adam can meet his hero, John Landis, but come up with a plan when they don't have special passes.If there is a downside to this, it's that there is only six episodes. Just as you are getting hooked and liking the characters, it's over real soon. Oh well. The bloopers and commentary are cool, but the featurettes are rather brief, not too deep, and appear to only be little commerical blips in between movies on FEARnet."Holliston" is a nice little surprise for a certain audience. It's not a highbrow show, but it took creator/director/writer/actor Adam Green a long time to get the show done exactly as he wanted it with no real interference. If you have an open mind and are into anything funky, then it could interest you too if you are not exactly into horror.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Holliston is a great show for fans of sitcoms and horror movies alike. There are so many references to horror movies in each episode, so if you are a die-hard horror fan you will relate to the characters. For me, the funniest part of the show is Dee Snider. Every time he is on screen, the show reaches infinite levels of hilarity. Tony Todd guest stars in an episode, playing a parody of himself. It is hilarious, and shows a different side of himself that we've never seen before. Tony Todd is famous for playing creepy roles like Candyman, and here he plays against type and shows his comedic side. There are also guest starring roles by John Landis, Danielle Harris, Kane Hodder, Seth Green, and Ray Wise in Season 1. The show isn't perfect as it does get repetitive at times, and I would have liked for there to have been more than six episodes. Still, a very good show!

reviewerName: The Brock Lesnar of Reviewing - The Most Hated
reviewText: I love most of Adam Green's movies and didn't know he had this show on fearnet, at first I wasn't to sure if I was going to like "Holliston" but by the end of the sixth episode I was in love! Its a funny show about 2 aspiring horror film makers and their struggles to make it big with lots of horror references and cameos.Adam Green and Joe Lynch basically play themselves along with Joe's girlfriend Laura who is an aspiring painter, Adam's imaginary friend Oderus Urungus (Dave Brockie from GWAR) who gives him advice, Adam's ex Corri who he is still madly obsessed an in love with and the duo's boss, Twisted Sister's own Dee Snider. The cast is great together as they go through Adam and Joe's day to day along with some great cameos from Bill Moseley, Danielle Harris, John Landis, Seth Green and Tony Todd. Seth and Tony have the best and funniest cameos of the bunch with Seth being a special effects guy with multiple personalities and Tony playing an ahole version of himself who shacks up with the duo while doing a new movie.The only thing that disappointed me about "Holliston" was that it was only 6 episodes, I really hope season 2 has more because its funny as hell with a horror twist that I absolutely enjoyed. If you like comedy/horror than you will love all 6 episodes of "Holliston" season 1.
Title: N/A
